definitions.definition: the process of comparing two or more people or things

examples.text: For Durkheim, comparison was the most important method of analysis in sociology.
Comparison with other oil-producing countries is extremely interesting.
The two situations **bear no comparison** *(= they are not at all similar)*.
I enclose the two plans for comparison.
Let's put them side by side for comparison.
Our problems don't bear comparison with those elsewhere.
The pandemic in some respects stands comparison with the Great Fire of London in 1666
The similarity between the two invites comparison.
a price-comparison site
to provide a basis for comparison
One of the groups serves as a comparison group or ‘control’ for the other.

definitions.definition: an occasion when two or more people or things are compared
definitions.sensetop: comparison of A and Bcomparison of A with Bcomparison between A and Bcomparison of A to Bcomparison with somebody/something

examples.text: The films are too different for a fair comparison.
a comparison of the rail systems in Britain and France
a comparison of men’s salaries with those of women
comparisons between Britain and the rest of Europe
a comparison of the brain to a computer *(= showing what is similar)*
It is difficult to **make a comparison** with her previous book—they are completely different.
You can **draw comparisons** with the situation in Ireland *(= say how the two situations are similar)*.
There is no published information that would allow a **direct comparison** with other regions or countries.
a comparison with other schools
a comparison of unemployment rates over the past 15 years
a comparison between figures for last year and this year

definitions.definition: used especially at the beginning of a sentence when the next thing that is mentioned is compared with something in the previous sentence

examples.text: By comparison, expenditure on education increased last year.
His problems seemed trivial by comparison.
The second half of the game was dull by comparison with the first.
The tallest buildings in London are small in comparison with New York's skyscrapers.
The glasses are small in comparison with the old ones.
Jane is still quite young, and Fiona seems old by comparison.

definitions.definition: to seem less important when compared with something else

examples.text: Last year's riots pale in comparison with this latest outburst of violence.
Our problems pale into insignificance when compared to theirs.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize the difference between two people or things that are being compared

examples.text: In terms of price there's no comparison *(= one thing is much more expensive than the other)*.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French comparesoun, from Latin comparatio(n-), from comparare ‘to pair, match’, from compar ‘like, equal’, from com- ‘with’ + par ‘equal’.
